Def.Name: Austrian Pine
Def.Description: European black pine is an introduced, medium-sized, two-needle pine. Mature height 66' - 165' tall. Fast growing and usually has a pyramidal form.
Def.Leaves: Dark green needles occuring as two per bundle. 3"-6" long, thick, stiff. May break cleanly when twisted.
Def.Twigs: Yellowish to greenish-brown. Not glaucous or bloomy.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Seed Cones: 3" - 4" long and nearly as wide.
Def.Bark: Plates are light grayish-brown to almost white. The bark becomes increasingly creviced with age.
Def.Range: European black pine is native to Europe and Asia. From Spain and Morocco east to eastern Turkey, south to Cypress, and north to northeastern Austria and the Crimea, Russia. In the United States its widely planted in northern states in New England, around the Great Lakes, and in the Northwest.
Def.Remarks: Wood similar to that of Scotch pine and Red pine, which is moderately hard and straight-grained, but rougher, softer, and not as strong. General construction and fuel. White-tailed deer may preference this ornamental over other ornamental species.
